My 83-year old  mother, who recovered from a "mild" case of Covid 19 back in March, suffered an arrhythmia in July and had to be sedated and have her heart shocked back into normal sinus rhythm.  Another friend who had what we believe was Covid 19 back in March ( unlike my parents, he was "too young" to be tested) has been in and out of the hospital for months with heart problems and finally had to have a Left-Ventricle Assist Device (LVAD) implanted in his heart.  He now has to have a charged battery with him at all times.    This is nothing to risk lightly!

A larger heart does NOT mean a stronger heart. Heart is a hollow organ, and it can grow "larger" in a few ways: anything other than a symmetrical growth in overall size is bad news.

If the heart is about the same size on the outside, but the walls are getting thicker towards the inside (a concentric growth), you lose out on the space available to fill with blood. This also stretches out the muscle in a way that is not optimal for producing adequate contraction force. This is most likely what's happening in myocarditis.

Alternatively, if the heart grows bigger on the outside, but only because the blood pressure is so high it blows up the ventricles like a balloon, it's also bad. This is the case for a stuck mitral/tricuspid valve (stenosis), a kink in the aorta (coarctation), etc.

IMO the most terrifying one is probably a normal size heart, but the interventricular septum (muscle wall separating left and right ventricle) gets big (a.k.a. HOCM). This has the same problem of concentric growth AND increased chance of arrhythmia. This is the "roll your eyes and drop dead" kind you might see on TV to an otherwise healthy college athlete. However, compared to the first two, this is also one where surgery can make the most difference.

I took ill back in March, at a point when it was practically impossible to get tested here in the UK. I had a long recovery, and a bizarre set of symptoms that didn't match the then-circulating description of Covid. I had confusion and severe brain fog, but no outright fever - although familiar locations seemed new to me, and I couldn't remember what day of the week it was, I didn't have a raised temperature. The most pressing thing I noticed was a tightness of breath - like having an iron brace around my lungs. As an asthmatic, it was actually quite a familiar sensation, so I just worked with my capacity. Since recovering though, I've repeatedly noticed irregularities in my heartbeat that were never there before, so this is a topic I've been following particularly closely.

I hope for my sake and for many others that some therapy becomes available to help either manage or repair the damage done, and I want to reiterate for all my fellow young people out there (I am myself in my mid-20s) - you're not indestructible, and even if you are strong and healthy, surviving the disease doesn't mean you'll get away unscathed. Wear a mask, maintain social distancing wherever possible, and when it becomes available, get yourself vaccinated.
